questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following conditions does not presents as pulsatile proptosis?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, hemangioma will not present with pulsatile proptosis. Causes of pulsatile proptosis: • Pulsating vascular lesions: • Caroticocavernous fistula- most common • Saccular aneurysm of ophthalmic artery • Transmitted cerebral pulsations in conditions with a deficient orbital roof: 430 
Sold by @itachibot • Congenital meningocele/meningoencephalocele • Neurofibromatosis • Traumatic or operative hiatus Causes of intermittent proptosis: • Orbital varix- most common • Periodic orbital edema Causes of reducible proptosis: • Orbital varix • Hemangioma • Caroticocavernous fistula

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient presents with unilateral non-pulsatile proptosis, which is compressible and 
increases on bending forward. No thrill or bruit is present. MRI shows a retrobulbar mass 
with enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The likely diagnosis from the above clinical scenario is orbital varix. The type of proptosis seen in orbital varix is non-pulsatile, intermittent, and reducible proptosis. 
On activities such as forward bending or lowering of the head, turning the head forcefully, 
hyperextension of the neck, and coughing, the varices fill up, causing proptosis, and then, they 
regress on shifting to a non-dependent position. All the other conditions listed, namely, carotid cavernous fistula, orbital encephalocele, and 
neurofibromatosis, present with pulsatile proptosis.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 26-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the head 2 months earlier presented with 
rapidly progressive swelling, pain, and diminishing vision in the left eye. The physical 
examination of the left eye revealed chemosis and pulsating proptosis. A bruit could be heard 422 
Sold by @itachibot with a stethoscope placed on the left temple. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of carotid–cavernous fistula. All the given options are causes of proptosis following trauma, but among these, only a 
carotid-cavernous fistula presents with the classic triad: • Pulsatile proptosis • Chemosis • Bruit Selective carotid angiography is the investigation of choice. A carotid-cavernous fistula requires a definitive treatment, which currently involves 
the endovascular technique. The fistula can usually be occluded with a balloon or coil, without the 
sacrifice of the carotid artery.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following conditions will present with pseudoproptosis?
questions.explanation:
431 
Sold by @itachibot Buphthalmos causes pseudoproptosis. The other listed conditions, namely, pseudotumors, orbital hemorrhage, and cavernous sinus 
thrombosis, produce actual proptosis. Pseudoproptosis is a condition in which the eyeball appears to be proptosed, but there is no actual 
forward displacement. Causes of pseudoproptosis: • Buphthalmos is the term used when the eyeball enlarges in children who develop congenital 
glaucoma before the age of 3 years. • Axial high myopia- increase in the size of the eyeball in myopia causes pseudoproptosis • Retraction of the upper lid • Enophthalmos of the opposite eye

questions.question:
Question 6: A 48-year-old lady presents with unilateral mild axial proptosis. On examination, the 
following nail and skin changes were seen as shown. Which of the following is the most 
appropriate next step of investigation?

options.a: CT scan to rule out meningioma
options.b: USG to rule out orbital pseudotumor
options.c: T3 and T4 measurement to check for thyrotoxicosis

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing thyroid acropachy and dermopathy is 
suggestive of Graves' disease. The most appropriate next step of the investigation is T3 and T4 
measurement to check for thyrotoxicosis. Thyroid ophthalmopathy is the most common cause of proptosis in adults, which may present 
as unilateral or bilateral, axial or non-axial, painful or painless proptosis. The image given below shows unilateral proptosis in the right eye.

questions.question:
Question 7: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and 
chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of thyroid ophthalmopathy. 432 
Sold by @itachibot Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of both bilateral and unilateral proptosis in 
an adult in the euthyroid state. The main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, 
periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy. Other options- Option A- Orbital pseudotumor presents with painful eye movements periorbital edema, 
erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia. Option C- Orbital lymphoma usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a 
painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant. Option D- Orbital cellulitis is usually a unilateral condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis. NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common clinical feature of Graves’ ophthalmopathy?
questions.explanation:

questions.question:
Question 9: A 40-year-old male presents with heat intolerance and weight loss for the past few weeks. He 
has lost 10 kgs despite having an increased appetite. On examination, he has a fine tremor of 
the hands, and his thyroid is enlarged. Lab investigations reveal low TSH and elevated T3 and 
T4. What is the most common ocular motility defect seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Grave's disease. The most common ocular motility 
defect seen in Grave's disease is elevator restriction. It occurs due to the fibrotic contracture of the inferior rectus muscle. The inferior rectus muscle 
has to relax during the elevation of the eye. The fibrosis of the muscle restricts its relaxation and 
thus elevation of the eye is restricted. There is an inability to look up (in both adducted and abducted positions) along with esotropia 
(fibrosis of the medial rectus). Only the belly of the muscle is involved in thyroid myopathy; the tendon is characteristically 
spared. Ocular motility restriction in order of frequency is as follows: • Elevation defect • Abduction defect, due to fibrosis of the medial rectus • Depression defect, due to fibrosis of the superior rectus • Adduction defect, due to fibrosis of the lateral rectus

questions.question: Question 10: What is known as the infrequent blinking seen in Graves’ ophthalmopathy?
questions.explanation: Infrequent blinking is known as Stellwag’s sign.

questions.question:
Question 11: A lady is referred from the medicine department for an eye exam due to gritty sensation in 
her eyes. She is a known case of hyperthyroidism. Her ophthalmic examination shows the 
following finding along with the inability to look up. Which of the following is not a treatment 
modality for this condition?
questions.explanation:
434 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical scenario of grittiness in the eyes (due to ocular dryness), hyperthyroidism and the 
image showing exophthalmos are suggestive of Graves ophthalmopathy. Beta-blockers are not indicated in the treatment of graves ophthalmopathy, however, they are 
used in the symptomatic management of hyperthyroidism. Treatment of thyroid ophthalmopathy: (A) Non-surgical management • Systemic steroids- These form the mainstay of the treatment. Oral, intravenous or orbital steroid 
injections can be used depending upon patient indications. (Option B) • Radiotherapy- Orbital radiation given in a dose of 2000 rads over 10-14 days can be considered 
in cases where steroids are ineffective/ contraindicated. It is contraindicated in cases of extensive 
thyroid eye disease as it can worsen it. (Option A) • Teprotumumab (IGF-1R inhibitor)- is used for persistent, corticosteroid-resistant disease or 
non-response to first-line treatment. It is effective in reducing proptosis and clinical activity in 
patients. (B) Surgical management: • Orbital decompression- It may be required for an acutely progressive optic neuropathy and/or 
exposure keratitis, in patients not responding to aggressive steroid therapy. (Option D) • Extraocular muscle surgery- Inferior rectus recession is the most commonly performed surgery. 
These should be performed after the orbital decompression since decompression may alter 
extraocular motility. Extraocular muscle surgery helps in achieving a binocular single vision in the 
primary gaze and reading position. • Eyelid surgery- This is done to correct eyelid retraction. Various surgeries that can be performed 
are mullerectomy, levator recession/ disinsertion, scleral grafts with LPS recession, recession of 
lower eyelid retractors, and blepharoplasty.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most 
probable cause ?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis. Features of cavernous sinus thrombosis include early involvement lateral rectus palsy (abducent 
nerve involvement) since it runs through the cavernous sinus. Oculomotor and trochlear nerve 
palsy occur later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. Other signs are 
proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in the mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, 
and dilated pupil. Options A- Retinoblastoma occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with 
leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint. Option B- Orbital pseudotumor presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival 
chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids. Option C- Orbital cellulitis presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular 
motility. 435 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 20-year-old man with a history of repeated pain over the medial canthus and chronic use of 
nasal decongestants presents to the OPD with high-grade fever and chills, headache, and 
bilateral proptosis. On further history, it is noted that the proptosis began in the right eye, 
and a few days later, the left eye was also affected. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis. Pain over the medial canthus and use of nasal decongestants indicate that the patient was 
suffering from sinusitis, which can spread to cause orbital cellulitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis, 
or panopthalmitis. The differentiating feature here is the presentation pattern and bilaterality of the proptosis. In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due to 
the spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through intercavernous communication. Also, 
cavernous sinus thrombosis presents with high-grade fever with chills, rigor, and headache. On the other hand, orbital cellulitis and panophthalmitis are unilateral conditions. Differential diagnosis of acute inflammatory proptosis: Clinical features

questions.question: Question 14: Among the following, which muscle is affected first in cavernous sinus thrombosis?
questions.explanation:
The first muscle to be affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis is the lateral rectus. Ophthalmoplegia in cavernous sinus thrombosis occurs in the following sequence: • 6th nerve palsy (lateral rectus palsy) occurring first of all as it passes through the cavernous 
sinus. • 3rd and 4th nerves are involved later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous 
sinus.

questions.question:
Question 15: MRI of a patient revealed features of right cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which of the 
following would not be seen in this patient?

options.a: Constricted right pupil in response to light

questions.explanation:
Dilation of the pupil will be seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis due to the involvement of the 3rd 
cranial nerve. 437 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A 40-year-old male presented with a 1-day history of fever, headache, and bilateral periorbital 
and mid-facial swelling. He had attempted to burst a furuncle in the inner margin of his right 
nostril 2 days back. On examination, marked facial and periorbital swelling with chemosis 
and proptosis are noted. MRI is suggestive of bilateral cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which of 426 
Sold by @itachibot the following veins is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Infection from the dangerous area of the face (the area from the corners of the mouth to the 
bridge of the nose, including the nose and maxilla) spreads to the cavernous sinus via 
the ophthalmic veins.

questions.question:
Question 17: A child is brought to the OPD with fever, severe pain, and swelling of the left eye. He was 
bitten by a dog over the eye a few days back. On examination, there is mild proptosis with 
restriction of ocular movements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of orbital cellulitis. It is the acute inflammation of the soft tissues of the orbit behind the orbital septum. It can occur 
due to exogenous infection (penetrating injuries) or extension of an endogenous infection (dental 
infection). It presents with fever, severe pain, and eye swelling which increases with movement, chemosis, 
axial proptosis, and restriction of ocular movements. Complications include subperiosteal abscess, 
orbital abscess, cavernous sinus thrombosis, and general septicemia. The image shows orbital cellulitis in the left eye. 438 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Endophthalmitis is defined as the inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball, 
i.e., uveal tissue and retina, associated with the pouring of exudates into the vitreous cavity, 
anterior chamber, and posterior chamber. Option C: Panophthalmitis is an intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball, including 
Tenon’s capsule. Option D: Preseptal cellulitis refers to infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital 
septum. In this condition, proptosis is absent and ocular movements are normal.

questions.question:
Question 18: An 8-year-old child presents with fever and painful swelling of the left eye. He is being treated 
for acute ethmoiditis for 5 days. On examination, the visual acuity in the left eye is 6/12, there 
is chemosis, axial proptosis, limitation of ocular motility in all directions, and RAPD. What is 
the most likely diagnosis? 427 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis of this patient is orbital cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis is the most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children. Ethmoidal sinusitis 
is the most common cause of orbital cellulitis in children. Orbital cellulitis presents with pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis. 
Decreased ocular motility and elevated intraocular pressure can be seen. Systemic symptoms 
include malaise and fever. A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve. With 
posterior exenteration cavernous sinus thrombosis, subdural empyema, and intracranial abscess 
develop. WARNING SIGNS: Dilated pupil, marked ophthalmoplegia, loss of vision, afferent pupillary 
defect, papilledema, and violaceous lids.

questions.question: Question 19: What is the surgery of choice for panophthalmitis?
questions.explanation:
The surgery of choice for panophthalmitis is an evisceration. Evisceration gives a better cosmetic 
outlook after the surgery and is hence preferred. Enucleation is contraindicated in 
panophthalmitis due to the risk of meningitis through the exposed meningeal sheath of the optic 439 
Sold by @itachibot nerve stump. Some definitions: • Evisceration- removal of the contents of the eyeball, leaving behind the sclera. It is done 
in panophthalmitis. • Enucleation- removal of the eyeball, with the maximum part of the optic nerve. Extraocular 
muscles are left behind. The length of the optic nerve removed is 10 to 15 mm. Absolute 
indications for enucleation are retinoblastoma and malignant melanoma. • Exenteration- mutilating surgery in which all the contents of the orbits along with the periorbita 
are removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreading 
from the eyeball. • Debulking- reduction of as much of the bulk (volume) of a tumor as possible. Nowadays, 
debulking of the orbit is preferred over exenteration.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 72-year-old female presents with normal visual acuity, diminished corneal sensation, and 
global impairment of ocular motility of the right eye. The patient also has a severe boring 
headache. The MRI shows an enhancing mass within the right cavernous sinus. The pain and 
ophthalmoplegia respond dramatically to corticosteroid therapy. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The patient presents with acute ophthalmoplegia with the involvement of ophthalmic division of 
trigeminal nerve that responds promptly to steroid therapy. The most likely diagnosis is 
Tolosa-Hunt syndrome. It is an idiopathic, sterile inflammation that primarily affects the cavernous sinus. It is 
characterized by painful acute ophthalmoplegia with or without the involvement of the optic nerve 
and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. The pain is described as gnawing or boring and may precede ophthalmoplegia. The inflammation and pain in patients typically responds rapidly and dramatically to 
corticosteroid therapy. However, it is a diagnosis of exclusion.

questions.question:
Question 21: The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome is 
best made by the dysfunction of which cranial nerve?
questions.explanation:
The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome is 
made by the dysfunction of the optic nerve (CN II). The optic nerve passes through the optic canal and does not enter the cavernous sinus. Patients 
with orbital apex syndrome manifest complete ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, decreased corneal 
sensation, and vision loss. They usually develop optic nerve signs such as relative afferent 
pupillary defect. Proptosis is often present, but patients do not always complain of pain.

questions.question:
Question 22: A patient was being evaluated for retro-orbital pain in the ward. After multiple investigations, 
he was diagnosed with Tolosa-Hunt syndrome. Which of the following findings will not be 
seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ipsilateral lateral rectus palsy due to 6th cranial nerve involvement is seen in Tolosa–Hunt 
syndrome, not contralateral. 440 
Sold by @itachibot Tolosa–Hunt syndrome refers to idiopathic, nonspecific, granulomatous inflammation, involving 
the superior orbital fissure and/or orbital apex and/or cavernous sinus. It is a unilateral eye 
condition. Clinically, it manifests as painful ophthalmoplegia and depending on the extent of involvement, it 
may present as superior orbital fissure syndrome or orbital apex syndrome. Superior orbital fissure syndrome is characterized by the following: • Pain, typically labeled as retro-orbital ache • Sensory loss/disturbances in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve • Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to the involvement of the 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerve 
involvement • Ptosis, due to 3rd nerve paralysis Orbital apex syndrome includes the following: • Features of superior orbital fissure syndrome described above • Features of optic nerve involvement, i.e., early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect. 441 
Sold by @itachibot Strabismus - Introduction, Symptomatology, and Evaluation
